function.name: typeRobust
function.param: identifier of the element to type the value for
value to type
function.comment:
This types the value in the target element, if the element exists. Otherwise it just passes silently.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: selectRobust
function.param: identifier of the element to select
value to type
function.comment:
This selects an option for a select list, if the select list exists. Otherwise it just passes silently.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: clickRobust
function.param: identifier of the element to click at
function.comment:
This clicks at the element, if it exists. Otherwise it just passes silently.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: isTimestampDownToMilliseconds
function.param: identifier of the element to parse the timestamp from
Expected timestamp, in milliseconds, since Epoch (January 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC)
function.comment:
Parse the given element as a timestamp and compare to the given timestamp, down to precision of milliseconds.
Do not use auto-generated form waitForTimestampDownToMilliseconds.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: isTimestampDownToSeconds
function.param: identifier of the element to parse the timestamp from
Expected timestamp, in milliseconds, since Epoch (January 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC)
function.comment:
Parse the given element as a timestamp and compare to the given timestamp, down to precision of seconds.
Do not use auto-generated form waitForTimestampDownToSeconds.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: isTimestampDownToMinutes
function.param: identifier of the element to parse the timestamp from
Expected timestamp, in milliseconds, since Epoch (January 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC)
function.comment:
Parse the given element as a timestamp and compare to the given timestamp, down to precision of minutes.
Do not use auto-generated form waitForTimestampDownToMinutes.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: isTimestampDownToPrecision
function.param: identifier of the element to parse the timestamp from
function.comment:
Parse the given element as a timestamp and compare to the given timestamp, down to given precision.
Do not use auto-generated form waitForTimestampDownToPrecision.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToMilliseconds
function.param: Label/name, usually reflecting an element or field, for which you want to get a distinct timestamp.
Precision, in milliseconds; 1 by default.
function.comment:
Just like sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToSeconds, but guaranteed timestamp separation is the given number of milliseconds.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToSeconds
function.param: Label/name, usually reflecting an element or field, for which you want to get a distinct timestamp.
Precision, in seconds; 1 by default.
function.comment:
Use to record the moment when you inserted/updated such a field, and you want this timestamp to differ from
any previous timestamps with this label, and/or
any future timestamps with this label
when comparing using given precision (in seconds). This makes sure that you get timestamps which can be compared as distinct. So it guarantees that timestamps with same label will have time distance between them at equal or greater than given precision.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToMinutes
function.param: Label/name, usually reflecting an element or field, for which you want to get a distinct timestamp.
Precision, in minutes; 1 by default.
function.comment:
Just like sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToSeconds, but the guaranteed timestamp separation is 1 minute.
Warning: This keeps a count only of timestamps notes since you started Selenium IDE. If you re-started it soon after the previous run which could record timestamps, make sure you wait for a sufficient period to get distinct new timestamps. (That shouldn't be a problem with sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToSeconds and sleepUntilTimestampDistinctDownToMilliseconds).
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: indexBy
function.param:
What to index by. Either
string - name of the column to index by
object { indexBy string, name of the field to index by; required. Values of this field should be unique within the source, unless you also use valuesUnique: false. See valuesUnique.
valuesUnique boolean, optional, defaults to false. It indicates whether the values of the index field (determined by indexBy) are unique. If valuesUnique is false and the value of the index field are not unique, then the result will contain less records than the source (only the last iterated record for any index value will be present in the result). If valuesUnique is false, then the result will contain arrays, one array per each index value, and each array will contain record(s) for its respective index value.
store string, name of the result stored variable; optional
}. You can pass it via =<>...<> notation as per http://selite.github.io/EnhancedSelenese.

Name of the stored variable which contains the source data to be indexed. If columnOrDetails is not an object, or if columnOrDetails.target is not set, then the result will replace the source (storedVars[sourceVariableName]).
function.comment:
Index data.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: clickRandom
function.param: XPath expression to locate the radio buttons (it can't be any other Selenium locator). Don't include leading 'xpath='. You probably want to use XPath 'contains' function, e.g. //input[ @type='radio' and contains(@id, 'feedback-') ].
Optional; name of the stored variable to store the selected value, it may include field or sub(sub...)field e.g. variableName.fieldName, variableName.fieldName.subfieldName...
function.comment:
This clicks at a random radio button from within a set of radio button(s) identified by locator.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: selectRandom
function.param: Locator of <select>...</select> to select an option for.

optional, either
a string which is the name of the stored variable to put the selected value in (see store below), or
an object in form {
excludeFirst: true - Whether to exclude the first option, optional
excludeLast: true - Whether to exclude the last option, optional
store: string - name of the stored variable to store the selected value, it may include field or sub(sub...)field e.g. variableName.fieldName, variableName.fieldName.subfieldName... }. You can pass it via =<>...<> notation as per http://selite.github.io/EnhancedSelenese.
function.comment:
This selects a random option from within <select>...</select> identified by the locator.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: typeRandom
function.comment:
Type random characters into an input. It always types at least 1 character.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.
function.param: Locator of the text input

optional, either
string - name of the stored variable to save the value to (see store below), or
an object in form {
minLength int, if present then it must be at least 1, otherwise it's set to 1. If type==='email', then minLength must be at least 7 (e.g. a@hi.it), otherwise it's set to 7. If type==='password' and minLength is not set, then it defaults to 9.
maxLength int, if present then it must be at least minLength; if not present, then input's 'maxlength' property is used; if that's not present, then 255
type string indicating type of the field (and what it can/should accept/refuse). Possible values:
'email'when generating an email address 'name'when generating a human name (and some random letters A-Za-z) 'word'word (random letters a-z) 'number'generates a non-negative number; see more options below 'text'generates random word(s) (and random letter-based text) 'html'like 'text', but it adds some simple HTML tags around some of the words. 'maxlength' applies to the length of the result HTML (including the tags). 'password'Password that contains at least one of a-z, A-Z, 0-9 and '!@#$%^&*()-_' 'ugly'This generates bad characters (possibly used for SQL injection, filesystem access). It will try to include all unique ugly characters at least once, so it may always generate more characters than minLength, therefore leaving some combinations untested. (Indeed, it will never overstep maxLength or input's 'maxlength' property, if maxLength isn't set.)
If type is not set and if you don't use characters, then the default characters used are: alphanumerics, space, underscore, dash -
characters String or array containing acceptable characters, or a regular expression that matches any acceptable characters. You can't use both type and characters with the same action call. htmlTagsArray of HTML tag names to use if type is 'html'. Optional. It's useful with applications/WYSIWYG editors that transform HTML (e.g. Xinha editor transforms <b> to <strong>, <i> to <em> and <strike> to <del>). decimal boolean, optional. If true, then generate a decimal number. Any minLength/maxLength (or HTML maxlength property of the input) will apply to number of letters used, i.e. to number of generated digits + 1 (for the decimal point)
scale int If set, max length of the decimal fraction (max. number of digits right of decimal point). It has to be higher than 0; if you pass scale: 0, it will be ignored.
max number (int or float) maximum value (inclusive, if 'scale' permits). Optional. Applied when type='number'. It has to be higher than zero; zero will be ignored. If used, then 'minLength', 'maxLength' (or 'maxlength' property) will be ignored. Indeed, if decimal is set and the result is smaller than max, then it may have more decimal places than max has.
min number (int or float) minimum value (inclusive). Optional, but it may be only used if 'max' is set. See 'max'.
store string name of the stored variable to store the selected value, it may include field or sub(sub...)field e.g. variableName.fieldName, variableName.fieldName.subfieldName...
}. You can pass it via =<>...<> notation as per http://selite.github.io/EnhancedSelenese.

function.name: typeRandomEmail
function.param: Locator of the text input where to type the generated email address
function.comment:
Type random email address, based on a name already typed in another element. If you don't want the email address to be based on any name, then use typeRandom with type='email' instead.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: selectMapped
function.comment:
TODO implement + comment
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: disableJavascript
function.comment:
Disable Javascript for the web application that is being tested
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: enableJavascript
function.comment:
Disable Javascript for the web application that is being tested
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: selectTopFrameAnd
function.param:
Either
string - a locator, or
array of locators, passed as `[ 'locator1', 'locator2'... ]` where each locator is an escaped Javascript string. You can use string expressions, not just string literals.
It's optional. If nothing is passed, then the command just selects the top frame.
function.comment:
It selects the top frame. Then it waits for any specified frames to become present. However, it doesn't wait for the top frame. For that you should use 'andWait' postifx for the last command that loaded the current page. Don't use selectTopFrameAndAndWait.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: ensureUnderWebRoot
function.param: Whether to reload the webroot, even when the current URL is under webroot. Boolean, optional, false by default.
function.comment:
It ensures that the location of the current window will be under webroot (defined in webRoot config field - see http://selite.github.io/Settings). If it is not so, or if you pass forceReload equal to true, then it opens webRoot in the current window.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: nop
function.comment: This does nothing. It serves when all you need is to evaluate Target and/or Value parameter, e.g. javascript{...} (see http://docs.seleniumhq.org/docs/02_selenium_ide.jsp#javascript-usage-with-non-script-parameters).

function.name: log
function.param: Message to log.
One of: debug, info, warn, error. Defaults to error (so that it's visible no matter what filter).
function.comment:
It logs the message to Selenium IDE log tab.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: getAttribute
function.param: Atribute locator: element locator, followed by @ and an attribute name. In addition to traditional getAttribute, this supports @innerText and @value. For example id=age@value.
function.comment:
Set an attribute on an element to a given value.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: setAttribute
function.param: Atribute locator, as per getAttribute: element locator, followed by @ and an attribute name. For example id=link@href.
Value to set.
function.comment:
Set an attribute on an element to a given value.
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: assertTrue
function.param: Javascript expression to evaluate.
function.comment:
Assert the given expression to be true (compared strictly).
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.

function.name: verifyTrue
function.param: Javascript expression to evaluate.
function.comment:
Verify the given expression to be true (compared strictly).
This command is a part of SeLite Commands.
